question: In the Young's double slit experiment, the intensity of light passing through each of the two double slits is <katex>$2\times10^{-2}Wm^{-2}$</katex>. The screen-slit distance is very large in comparison with slit-slit distance. The fringe width is <katex>$\beta$</katex>. The distance between the central maximum and a point P on the screen is <katex>$x=\frac{\beta}{3}$</katex>. Then the total light intensity at that point is
explanation: Phase difference <katex>$\phi = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \Delta x = \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} (d \sin \theta) \approx \frac{2\pi}{\lambda} \frac{xd}{D}$</katex>. Since <katex>$\beta = \lambda D / d$</katex>, <katex>$\phi = \frac{2\pi x}{\beta}$</katex>. Given <katex>$x = \beta/3$</katex>, <katex>$\phi = 2\pi/3$</katex>. Resultant intensity <katex>$I_R = I_{max} \cos^2(\phi/2) = 4I_0 \cos^2(\phi/2)$</katex>. <katex>$I_R = 4(2\times10^{-2}) \cos^2(\pi/3) = 8\times10^{-2} (1/2)^2 = 2\times10^{-2}$</katex>.
